awd_abstract_narration:
The School of Mathematics at the Institute for Advanced Study (IAS) annually hosts collaborative research visits of one-semester or one-year duration by approximately 70 mathematicians.  This award annually supports visits for 18 postdoctoral fellows and 6 mid-career mathematicians, who join 45 or more other mathematicians supported by funds from other sources.  In first-rate academic facilities located in a peaceful setting with a minimum of distractions, the School provides this diverse community of scholars with an interactive environment rich in mathematical content and conducive to collaboration. The presence of nearby Princeton University adds to the breadth of mathematics that is available to IAS visitors.  Each year the IAS conducts a special program focused on a particularly exciting field of mathematics. The programs for the next three years will include "Univalent Foundations of Mathematics" (2012), "Non-Equilibrium Dynamics and Random Matrices" (2013), and "Algebraic Geometry and Hodge Theory" (2014).  Approximately one third of visitors come especially to participate in such programs.  The School is dedicated to furthering the education of its postdoctoral fellows and strongly encourages the participation of women and members of other groups under-represented in mathematics. 

The School of Mathematics is devoted to supporting fundamental research at the highest level and to fostering mathematical talent.  It is led by eight permanent faculty members whose expertise spans a wide spectrum of mathematics.  The School is a center for new collaborations and new lines of research.  Junior mathematicians benefit from mentoring by faculty and from interactions with senior scholars.  Mid-career and senior mathematicians consolidate their research projects and explore new research directions.  A large fraction of this country's mathematical leaders are former IAS visitors.  The School's emphasis on a unified mathematical perspective and bringing together a diverse group of mathematicians has led to numerous unanticipated mathematical developments.  Historically, many of the most important developments in mathematics have originated at the IAS -- this is reflected, for example, by the numerous Fields Medalists whose work is connected with the IAS.  All IAS lectures are videotaped and are available to the public.

Outcomes Report for 2012-2017

The Institute's faculty and the presence of leading mathematicians from around the world make the Institute for Advanced Study (IAS) an ideal place to create new mathematical knowledge. Interactions among mathematicians in different fields lead to new interdisciplinary advances and create an environment to train the next generation of leaders, which was the focus of this grant. The grant supported 18 postdoctoral fellows and six (6) mid-career scientists annually, all of whom worked alongside an additional 20-25 postdoctoral fellows and 25-30 mathematicians in more advanced career levels. The quality of the program can be seen in the fact that 85% of our postdoctoral fellows join top tier institutions, and that 13 of the last 36 Fields medalists (the Fields medal is considered the equivalent of the Nobel prize in mathematics) have been postdoctoral fellows at IAS within 3 years after their PhD.

During the reporting period the Institute organized five topical programs addressing an array of important topics. These ranged from the mathematical foundations for using computers as proof assistants (Univalent Foundations), statistical mechanics, the geometry of three-dimensional spaces, algebraic geometry, and homological mirror symmetry (HMS) which addresses mathematical issues underlying string theory. The topical programs represent about a third of the scientific activities at IAS. Significant advances were made in all programs. With respect to the HMS program there is now a general understanding that one 'sees light at the end of the tunnel'. The univalent foundation program jump-started a world-wide activity of bringing certain parts of mathematics into a form, which make the logical arguments computer checkable. This makes it necessary to reformulate the foundations of mathematics by replacing set theory and standard logic by a different framework called type theory. There were several highlights during the algebraic geometry program, most notably a deep result by Hacon/McKernan/Xu in their construction of compact moduli spaces for stable varieties. The three-manifold program brought together a variety of researchers from different fields. The activity was prompted by a recent mathematical breakthrough of I. Agol on the Haken problem. I. Agol was leading this activity as the distinguished visiting professor. The statistical physics program was concerned with the question of how two central themes of mathematical physics - random matrix theory and non-equilibrium dynamics - are related, and it involved the leading researchers world-wide, among them M. Hairer who was awarded the Fields medal the same year. During the grant period the faculty members R. Taylor and J. Bourgain, as well as the I. Agol, leading the three-manifold program, were awarded the break-through prize in mathematics.
